questions.text: Which of the following timelines would be included in the perinatal period as per WHO?

choices.text: 37th week of gestation to 28 days after birth
20th week of gestation to 7 days after birth
28th week of gestation to 28 days after birth
22nd week of gestation to 7 days after birth

questions.solution:
The WHO states that the perinatal period commences at 22 completed weeks and ends at seven completed days after birth - 154 days. It corresponds to when the fetus weighs 500g or more.

This definition is not to be confused with the period used for the calculation of the perinatal mortality rate (PMR). To calculate the PMR, a fetal weight above 1000 g is considered, which is achieved at 28 weeks of gestation. Therefore, for all statistical purposes, international comparisons, and calculation of perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is considered.

Perinatal period: from the 22nd week.

Perinatal mortality rate calculation: from the 28th week.

The neonatal period is defined as the first 28 days after birth. Infancy is defined as the first year of life.

The image below shows various time periods. Only the time period for perinatal mortality and the perinatal period are different as shown in the image. For others, corresponding mortality rates are calculated using the same time periods shown.

questions.text: You would classify a baby as post-term if it is born after ________
questions.solution: Post-term infants are those born after 42 completed weeks of gestation, as calculated from the mother’s last menstrual period, regardless of weight at birth.

questions.text: You would classify a baby as a very low birth weight baby if the weight of the baby is found to be less than _____ kg.
questions.solution:
A very low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1.5 Kg. They are often premature (<37 weeks of gestation).

A low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <2.5 Kg.

An extremely low birth weight baby is one whose birth weight is <1 kg.

questions.text: Reena, a 34-year-old lady with gestation diabetes mellitus delivers an LGA baby at 37 weeks. What would the birth weight of this child be?
questions.solution:
Infants with birth weight greater than the 90th percentile for their gestational age are called large for gestational age (LGA) babies.

Maternal diabetes and obesity are predisposing factors for LGA babies. They have a higher incidence of: 

  • Birth injuries:  
    • Brachial plexus injury
    • Phrenic nerve injury
    • Cephalohematomas
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Polycythemia
  • Congenital heart disease

questions.text: As the intern assisting in the labor room, you are tasked with administering Vitamin K  to the term newborns with no complications. Which of the following dose and route would you use for administration?
questions.solution:
All newborn infants are to be administered vitamin K at a dose of 0.5–1 mg intramuscularly, to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn (HDN).

However, for newborns with vitamin K deficiency, the dose of vitamin K administered is 1–5 mg intravenously.

questions.text: A term neonate born by normal vaginal delivery is diagnosed with hypothermia. Which of the following is not a physiological response for heat regulation in this baby?

choices.text: Breakdown of brown fat with noradrenaline secretion

questions.solution:
Neonates do not generate heat by shivering.

Heat production in neonates happens by increasing the metabolic rate and oxygen consumption by releasing norepinephrine, which results in non-shivering thermogenesis through beta-oxidation of brown fat. This sympathetic surge also causes cutaneous vasoconstriction.

Increased physical activity - crying, increased body movements, and muscular activity also contribute to thermogenesis.

Preterm and small-for-gestational-age (SGA) infants have scanty brown fat stores.

questions.text: You are conducting the routine newborn assessment of a 2.3 kg baby born 10 minutes back. You would classify the neonate as having cold stress if you notice the body temperature to be:
questions.solution:
A temperature of 36.0 to 36.4°C categorizes a neonate as having cold stress.

An infant’s normal body temperature is 36.5 to 37.5 °C. It is measured in the apex of the baby's axilla by holding the thermometer for at least 3 minutes.

Hypothermia is an axillary temperature of <36.5 °C.

  • Cold stress: 36.0 to 36.4 °C
  • Moderate hypothermia: 32 to 35.9 °C
  • Severe hypothermia: <32 °C

Hyperthermia is an axillary temperature of >37.5 °C.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida delivers a preterm baby at 33 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2 kg. She is advised to hold her child as shown below.  Which of the following statements about this method is false?

choices.text: Safety and thermal protection is equivalent to incubators
Reduces severe morbidity in the newborns
Should be performed only by the mother

questions.solution:
Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) can be carried out by the mother or any other caregiver.

KMC was introduced for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns. It has 4 components—

  • Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother’s chest.
  • Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Support for mother and family for child care.

Evidence shows that-

  • It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection (measured by mortality)
  • Reduces severe morbidity by way of facilitating breastfeeding
  • Humanization of neonatal care
  • Promoted bonding between mother and child

Eligibility criteria for KMC:

It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies. Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy. Initiation of KMC can vary with the birth weight of the baby.

  • Birth weight <1200 g - It may take days to weeks for initiation of KMC
  • Birth weight =1200-1800 g - Only a few days may be taken before KMC initiation
  • Birth weight >1800 g - KMC can be initiated immediately after birth

All mothers without any serious illness can provide KMC.

Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breast in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.

KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Note: 

Incubatory care, feeding via nasal catheter, and prevention of infection are part of intensive care for low birthweight babies.

World Kangaroo Care Awareness Day is a global healthcare awareness event observed annually on 15th of May with an intention of spreading the benefits. Studies show that infants who underwent KMC had a low death count during the first-year follow-up. In addition, they also had lower rates of school absenteeism, hyperactivity, aggression, and socio-deviant behaviour among young adults than the control group after 20 years of follow-up.

questions.text: You are the intern posted in the labor room and are tasked with calculating the gestational maturity of the infants delivered. As per the expanded New Ballard scoring, what will be the lowest and highest scores you can obtain?
questions.solution:
The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age.

An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score?
questions.solution:
Scarf sign is a component of the neuromuscular criteria for maturity according to the expanded new Ballard score.

Scarf sign: If the infant's arm is pulled medially across the chest (as shown in the image below),

  • In a hypotonic infant, the elbow will cross the midline.
  • In a term infant with a normal tone, the elbow will not reach the midline.

Neuromuscular criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score) include:

  1. Posture
  2. Square window (wrist)
  3. Arm recoil
  4. Popliteal angle
  5. Scarf sign
  6. Heel to ear

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score) include:

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Eye/ear
  4. Plantar crease 
  5. Breast
  6. Genitals

The expanded new Ballard score is used to assess the physical and neuromuscular maturity of the newborn by scoring six criteria and thereby calculating the gestational age. It is accurate between 20 to 44 weeks. 

The lowest score on the expanded New Ballard Score is -10, which corresponds to 20 weeks gestational age, and the highest score is 50, which corresponds to 44 weeks gestational age. An increase in the score by 5 points corresponds to an increase of 2 weeks gestational age

questions.text: A 1.8 Kg neonate is born to a 24-year-old primigravida with no antenatal checkups.  While calculating the physical maturity of the neonate by the new Ballard scoring, which of the following criteria would you not take into account?
questions.solution:
Palmar surface is not a component of the physical criteria for maturity according to the expanded New Ballard score.

Physical criteria for maturity (according to the expanded New Ballard score):

  1. Skin
  2. Lanugo
  3. Eye/ear
  4. Plantar crease (Not palmar surface)
  5. Breast
  6. Genitals

questions.text: While examining a healthy term neonate, you notice that the baby passes greenish-black colored stools.  This color is due to -
questions.solution:
The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin.

Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the oxidation of bilirubin).

Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next few weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system. Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools.

Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.

questions.text: When does the parachute reflex disappear?

choices.text: At birth and reappears at 9 months

questions.solution:
The parachute reflex has its onset at 7–8 months of age. It is fully developed by 10-11 months of age and remains throughout life.

It can be evoked by holding the infant’s trunk and then suddenly lowering the infant as if he or she were falling. The arms will spontaneously extend to break the infant’s fall.

This reflex is a prerequisite to walking.

questions.text: A 6-day old infant is being examined. While checking the reflexes, a brisk Moro's reflex is noted. Which of the following conditions is a likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
A brisk Moro reflex can be seen in neonates with hypoglycemia. 

In hypoglycemic babies, there is an activation of the autonomic system, which results in jitteriness. Newborns often exhibit this as an exaggerated Moro reflex.

The Moro reflex is a primitive reflex that is very sensitive to the infant's level of alertness. It is elicited by supporting the infant in the semierect position and allowing the infant’s head to fall backward onto the examiner’s hand.

An animated gif of normal response to Moro's reflex where there is symmetrical extension and abduction of the upper extremities, followed by flexion of the upper extremities is shown below

The Moro reflex disappears by 6 months of age in normal infants.

Absent Moro reflex: caused by significant generalized disturbance of the CNS

  • Stage III HIE
  • Kernicterus

Asymmetric Moro reflex: feature of the root, plexus, or nerve disease

  • Fractured clavicle
  • Brachial plexus injury (Erb's palsy)
  • Hemiparesis

Brisk Moro reflex: 

  • Neonatal hypoglycemia
  • Can also be a normal variant in healthy infants
  • Stage I HIE

Exaggerated, stereotyped, non-habituating Moro reflex is a feature of severe bilateral intrauterine cerebral disturbance, perhaps because of the release of the brain stem from inhibitory cortical influences. It is seen in conditions such as the following:

  • Hydranencephaly
  • Severe micrencephaly 

Moro reflex in different stages of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE):

  • Stage I HIE (mild): Brisk
  • Stage II HIE (moderate): Weak/incomplete
  • Stage III HIE (severe): Absent

Option A: In kernicterus, there is a deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brain stem. Hence, the Moro reflex is absent 

Option C: In stage III HIE, the muscles are flaccid and the infant is comatose. Thus, the Moro reflex is absent. 

Option D: Erb's palsy results from an injury to the brachial plexus. So, the reflex is absent on the side of injury as the nerve supplying the muscles involved (efferent of the reflex) is affected.

questions.text: You are demonstrating findings in a pediatric OSCE examination on a 4-day old neonate. On turning the baby's head to the left, you obtain the finding as shown below. At what age does this reflex normally disappear?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric tonic neck reflex (ATNR) disappears by 6 months postnatally.

The tonic neck reflex is produced by manually rotating the infant’s head to 1 side and observing for the characteristic fencing posture (extension of the arm on the side to which the face is rotated and flexion of the contralateral arm).

An obligatory tonic neck response, in which the infant becomes “stuck” in the fencing posture, is always abnormal and implies a CNS disorder.

Note: According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: A first-time mother rushes to the OPD with her 4-day old infant and worriedly points to the rash that appears as shown below. You reassure her of its harmless, transient nature.  On microscopic examination, these papular lesions on an erythematous base will reveal ________
questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of erythema neonatorum. Wright stained smear of the contents of the pustule will show an abundance of eosinophils.

They are papular lesions on an erythematous base, distributed over the trunk and face predominantly. They are seen 1-3 days after birth and may persist for up to a week, after which they resolve spontaneously.

Neutrophils are seen in pustular melanosis. 

 

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 5-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. A lesion that was present since birth is noticed as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots or dermal melanocytosis.

Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.
